lines.text: I pray that on the march to New York, Washington attacks us. I'll turn on him and crush him in one blow. Then let the French try to save him.
I want Arnold. I'll hang that traitor if it's the last thing I do on God's earth.
You can't ignore history, George!
Oh, by God I can! If only it would ignore me.
You reenlisted?
A few months of good food, warm bed and warm wife was all I could stand. I had get back to the hunger and misery brigade so I could have something to complain about again.
[Eban moves to reenlist]
Have you lost your senses? You've done more then your bloody share!

[of Washington]
What if everybody quits him? What if he quits us?
This is how it begins. We are striking the first blows in this very room. Major, you and I will be starting a war.
Sir, this weather will wet the men's powder. Our muskets won't fire.
Then you must use your bayonets, sergeant. Trenton must be taken.
If this attack fails, and we're trapped in Jersey, it's all over.
It's all over in any event if we don't try.
[in front of a row of huge cannons]
Gentlemen, let's bid general Howe good morning.
[addressing a meeting of mutiny-minded soldiers]
Gentlemen, you'll permit me to put on my spectacles, as I have grown not only grey but also blind in the service of my country.
No punishment is too great for the man who builds his fortune on his country's ruin.

[to Continental Soldier]
Chest in! Chest in, gut out!
[to Hamilton]
What is wrong here?
You've got it backwards, Baron, it's "chest out, gut in."
Oh, gut in, not out. Like Von Steuben!
[laughs]
